LOs: Find the missing addend in a 2-digit addition problem

questions.answer_explanation: Addition is commutative, meaning the order of the numbers does not matter.
LOs: Understand the commutative property of addition

questions.q_text: Which method is useful when adding 287 + 465 quickly? Circle the correct option.
questions.answer_explanation: Regrouping is necessary when the sum of the digits in a column exceeds 9, requiring a carry to the next column.
LOs: Awareness of the concept of regrouping in addition

questions.q_text: Imagine you're designing a pendulum clock. If you increase the mass of the bob, will the clock run faster, slower, or stay the same? Explain your reasoning.
questions.a: The clock would run at the same speed because the time period of a pendulum does not depend on its mass.
questions.answer_explanation: The pendulum's time period is independent of mass due to equal acceleration from gravity for all masses.
questions.concept: Mass does not affect time period
common_misconceptions: Lighter bobs are slowed down more by air

questions.q_text: Which of the following motions is an example of an oscillation?

options.option_text: A pendulum swinging back and forth
A car driving around a circular track repeatedly
options.option_misconception: Confusion between oscillatory and circular motion

options.option_text: A person jogging back and forth across a field
options.option_misconception: Thinking any repeated motion is an oscillation

questions.answer_explanation: Only the pendulum motion is a true oscillation as it moves back and forth about a central position.
common_misconceptions: Confusion between circular and oscillatory motion

questions.q_text: A student measures the time for 20 swings of a pendulum and divides the total time by 20. What are they trying to find, and why is this method useful?
questions.a: They are finding the time period of the pendulum. This method reduces errors that come from trying to time a single swing.
questions.answer_explanation: Averaging over multiple swings reduces the impact of timing errors and improves accuracy.
common_misconceptions: Dividing swings by time instead of time by swings
Thinking the stopwatch must start only when the pendulum is at its peak

questions.q_text: True or False: A heavier pendulum bob swings faster because gravity pulls it down harder.
questions.answer_explanation: Gravity affects all masses equally, so the time period stays the same regardless of mass.
questions.concept: Mass does not affect time period
common_misconceptions: Gravity’s pull makes heavier bobs move faster

questions.q_text: You increase the length of the string in your pendulum setup. What happens to the time period and why?
questions.a: The time period increases because the pendulum has to travel a longer path, which takes more time.
questions.answer_explanation: A longer string increases the arc length, causing the swing to take more time.
common_misconceptions: Heavier bob at the end needs to catch up

questions.q_text: Which of the following best explains why we measure multiple oscillations instead of just one?

options.option_text: Because it makes the pendulum swing more accurately
options.option_misconception: Belief that the pendulum itself becomes more accurate

options.option_text: Because it helps cancel out small timing errors in measurement
Because it’s more fun to watch it swing many times
options.option_misconception: Misunderstanding scientific purpose behind repeated trials

options.option_text: Because more oscillations means less gravity resistance
options.option_misconception: Invented idea of 'gravity resistance' increasing over time

questions.answer_explanation: Measuring multiple swings and averaging helps reduce human timing errors.
common_misconceptions: Gravity affects time more with more swings

questions.q_text: A student says: 'The pendulum keeps swinging forever unless something stops it.' What would you say to help them understand what actually happens?
questions.a: I would explain that friction and air resistance slow the pendulum down over time, so it eventually stops.
questions.answer_explanation: Energy is lost due to air resistance and friction, so the pendulum slows and stops eventually.
common_misconceptions: Forgetting energy loss due to air and friction

questions.q_text: Which of the following factors affect the time period of a pendulum? Select all that apply.

options.option_misconception: Believes wider swings always take longer
Confuses damping effect with time period itself

questions.answer_explanation: Only the length of the string affects the time period, assuming small amplitudes and minimal air resistance.
common_misconceptions: Amplitude significantly changes time for small angles
Air resistance changes the formula-based time period
